p: True, we have not vanquished HIV from our world, but we have made substantial progress in preventing its spread and improving health outcomes for those who are living with the virus—even in the absence of a vaccine or curative treatment. Our national progress has been such that the United States has now set a goal to reduce new HIV infections by 75% come 2025 [ 14]. Without denying the importance of prophylaxis that can prevent the acquisition of HIV [ 15] or the impact of effective treatments that can reduce viral load such that the risk of sexual transmission is essentially nil [ 16], we would not be able to realistically visualize the end of AIDS in the United States without the continued public investment in systems that are necessary to prevent infection, improve health outcomes for those living with HIV and monitor changes in disease spread and outcome. Which brings us back to the point of this commentary. We must not allow ourselves to fall into a cycle of “neglect” by ignoring the threat of future pandemics once this initial wave of SARS-CoV-2 has passed.
